A timeless classic. Remains a really enjoyable experience almost 15 years after its initial release.
one of my personal favorites of all time
I like the first one more. But this is fine wine.

It is a half-game in comparison with half-life 1. Let me explain. 

I played it back as a kid and it was quite interesting but after looking at its roots... 

I finished half life 1 (Couldn't play it before due to the young age). 
Solid story with breaching into unkown worlds (Or more likely aliens breaching into our own world) by a chain of suspicious accidents was continued in the sequel with something that I would rather not talk about. 

Aliens won, we are so so opressed, go kill the bad guy and become a hero. Wow, so much thinking went into that.
Plot of this game doesn't make you wonder. It is just: alien benefecator - bad, you're -  good! 

Boring characters with the still mute Gordon Freeman.  Character development have come such a long way over the years and it pains me to see what was considered cool before. Villain leaves nothing to remeber and even g-man somehow loses his mystery. 

Exploration is boring and many parts of the game indeed look like eastern Europe but with the alien sticker applied to it. Water gliding area was the single thing worth mentioning. 

The overall feel is that half life 2 was dumbed down to an outrageous degree where it doesn't feel like a worthy adventure anymore, definetely not in 2020. 

"So why it is so bad if so many people liked it?" - Quite simple. There just weren't anything else back in the day. Good graphics for the time, excellent engine, unique things to do and plot that just EXISTS were still novelty things in the ol' 2004 and a considerable amount of years after it. 

But I look at all of the games with modern eyes and as much as I can - unbiased views and I believe you should do to, rating games well just because they were good back then is pretty stupid, don't you think? Which leads to a simple question: is it worth playing it TODAY? 

And the answer is simple: No. Story feels very cliche now and gameplay doesn't hold up to the everchanging industry. 
Save your buck and buy half-life 1, it is an experience that still feels fresh even in the modern day and age.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
This game is a MUST PLAY for people new to the Half-Life franchise or even just casual gamers. This game is one of my favorite games of all time, and there's a good reason why: IT'S JUST SO DAMN GOOD!

Before I talk about the actual content of the game, I'm quickly just going to talk about the look, feel, and sound of the game.

The graphics, though almost 16 years old, are still better than some of the games made today, and the materials they picked really suited the atmosphere of each environment. The sound design, while not the best, still is very good; you can hear the slosh below your feet when stepping through a swampy environment, you can hear the growl of nearby enemies, and the gun sounds are really great. Where the game shines most sound-wise, is through the music. Kelly Bailey is a god at creating eerie music tracks that match each environment, and is especially good at creating rock-like fight tracks.

Alright, now it's time to move onto (of course) my favorite part of the game: the game itself. This section may be long because I just have so many good things to say about this game, so I'll try to format it nicely, so there's some structure to it.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]Overview[/b]
Half-Life 2 is very similar to Half-Life 1 in its gameplay. There are physics puzzle sections, combat sections, driving sections, boating(?) sections, etc. The main differences between HL2 and HL1 are that HL2 has a waaay better physics engine, has more cleverly designed puzzles, varies a lot more in its gameplay, and has more character interactions. HL2 has a few less weapons than HL1, but it makes up for it by offering more gameplay mechanics and diversity each chapter.

[b]Combat and Gunplay[/b]
While HL2 has less guns than HL1, the gunplay is still very satisfying. The guns sound good, and it's always a blast ripping through enemies. A nice edition to the combat of HL2, is that the combine enemies --which will probably be the most common enemy type-- make a ringing tone when they die, which makes it easier to know when they have died. HL2, while taking away a lot of enemies of HL1, also introduces a lot of new ones, which I won't mention here in order not to spoil it.

[b]Story[/b]
 The story isn't the best I've ever experienced, but it is still very good. You grow pretty attached to the friends you make along the way, and the story is nicely paced.

[b]Level Design[/b]
This is one of the strongest aspects of the game. The materials and world design mesh (pun intended) very well together. Each chapter of the game presents a new, interesting environment for you to explore. While the maps are very linear, they still have some bonus ammo and healthkits.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
There are still many things I wanted to include in this review but couldn't, because it would just take me too long to write, but here are my closing thoughts: you can't really understand the greatness of HL2 until you've played it yourself. It's one of the greatest gaming experiences I've ever had, and severely under-priced, for what it offers.

"Time, Dr. Freeman? Is it really that time again?"

HL2 is a step up from the original Half-Life in terms of gameplay, and continues on with the story from Half-Life one.

There are new game mechanics in HL2 that prevent this game being too similar to the original. For starters there are some really fun vehicle sequences in the game which are brand new, and the addition of a Gravity Gun opens up a whole new range of gameplay logic puzzles for you to solve in order to progress.

For sure there are some great firefight sequences as well, and the story-telling does make you think a bit about government propaganda when you can see - as clear as day - what's going on in the world. 

It's a classic for a good reason.
[i] Half-Life 2 [/i] is widely considered to be one of the best P.C. games ever made. It was a pioneer in passive storytelling, and is still enjoyable to this day.

Well, 

I just finished this game for the 3rd time today. And even after 3rd time I enjoyed this game. Good story, good graphics, good game engine. Only problem I had was at Chapter 10: Anticitizen One, when NPCs were invisible (fixed by replaying game from first save I had from that Chapter) and one time when I had some weird game error that just closed the game.

Anyway, I highly recommend to play Half-Life 2 (optionally play Half-Life before starting this game). :)
